newsitem.title: FRANCE: Waigel sees German '97 deficit under 3 pct of GDP.
newsitem.headline: Waigel sees German '97 deficit under 3 pct of GDP.

text.p: German Finance Minister Theo Waigel said on Wednesday on arrival for a meeting with his French counterpart Jean Arthuis that Germany was in a position to keep its deficit below three percent of gross domestic product this year.
That would put it in line to meet the deficit criterion for European monetary union.
Both Germany and France are in a good position to achieve 2.5 percent economic growth this year, Waigel added.

Waigel told Reuters Germany would reach the deficit target because it had addressed the risks in its social security system, and no higher budget deficits were expected at the federal or state levels.
Waigel noted in this connection savings measures decided on Tuesday in Germany's health care system.
The European Union will decide in about one year, based on 1997 data, what countries will participate in EMU at the January 1999 start.
